Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Characterization and molecular modification of semiconductor nano-devices
Award.AbstractNarration:
Semiconductors are playing an interesting role in the development of new medical technologies. Design of nano-devices capable of real-time, on-site medical diagnostics for the improvement of patient care requires understanding of the synthesis, physical properties and effects of molecular modification of the surface of these materials, which change characteristics in specific environments. These so-called field effect transistors (FETs) respond to the electric field or electric charge of surface-bound species. Putting molecules on the surface may increase the FET's performance while specific functionalization of the surface for desired biomolecules is required for medical implications. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Jianhua Zhao at the Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Dr. Zhao's expertise in growth and characterization of nanostructures will facilitate production of single crystalline, high purity nanostructures utilizing a state-of-the-art molecular beam epitaxy growth environment as well as ample fabrication and measurement instruments.

Synthesis and structural and electrical characterization of sub-100 nanometer scale semiconductor materials is essential for application of nano-electronic devices. The project will focus on electrical transport measurements to evaluate the efficacy of these materials in FETs: two and four probe current-voltage relationship, electrical response to applied back-gate potentials, and resistance vs. temperature. The materials to be studied, gallium arsenide (GaAs) and indium arsenide (InAs), both exhibit electrical characteristics determined exclusively by the material due to the presence of Ohmic contacts. GaAs also offers the opportunity to study the effects of highly resistive Schottky barrier contacts. As a necessary step in the utilization of the nano-FETs for biosensing applications, the project will explore selective molecular functionalization of the nanowires via amine-terminated thiol molecules and passivation of the substrate by hydrophobic molecules, improving device functionalities. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

ProgramReference.Text: US CHINA COOP IN BASIC SCIENCE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This EAPSI research was conducted in the field of condensed matter and materials physics. This field is an increasingly popular avenue for nanomaterial synthesis and device design. The particular topic investigated during the funding period was on the molecular modification of well ordered semiconductor surfaces. The work was completed in collaboration with Professor Jianhua Zhao's group at the State Key Laboratory of Superlattices and Microstructures, Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Science in Beijing, CN. Professor Zhao is an expert in her field of nanostructure growth and characterization, providing an exemplary environment to carry out the desired project. The research is instrumental in my personal progression towards obtaining my doctoral degree while providing significant advancement in the topic of molecular deposition on semiconductors.

Nano fabrication is an imperative avenue for the continued miniaturization of every day devices. Much work has been completed on synthesis and characterization of nanostructures, focusing on both metals and semiconductors, but one of the current issues preventing advancement is devising a way to self-assemble the nanostructures in highly specified, complex patterns. Here we turn to the investigation of molecular patterning on surfaces via dip-pen nanolithography (DPN). DPN offers distinct advantages over other lithography techniques including the ability to pattern molecules down to tens of nanometers and flexibility offered by direct-write techniques. The deposition of molecules on gold via the gold-sulfur interaction has been extensively studied over the past decade. However, gold is not an ideal substrate for many applications. Initial results show the ability to extend the work completed on gold to oxide-free semiconductors. Semiconductors are already investigated in a wide range of fields, including spintronics and sensing applications. The ability to pattern on semiconductors at the nanoscale with the control achieveable by DPN opens new pathways for device design and implementation.

The researchers have implemented a wet-etch technique to strip the existing oxide from the surface of the semiconducting substrate. This leaves the surface vulnerable to molecular modification. Experiments carried out during the funding period show that the deposition of the thiol, 16-mercaptohexadecanoic acid (MHA), onto a specific semiconducting substrate is not achieveable without adequate passivation. After passivation, DPN can be carried out similarly to deposition on gold. Demonstrated in the results to be published is the direct patterning via DPN on the substrate after passivation. Deposition has been verified by two separate experimental techniques, lateral force microscopy and x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy. Investigated were the ink diffusion by monitoring the spot size vs. dwell time in a given environment. The investigators were able to pattern the chemical formula for the semiconducting substrate, "GaMnAs", on the surface to demonstrate the complexity. The minimum linewidth achieved in deposition was around 70 nm.

To our knowledge, this is the first time such experiments have been successful. Demonstrating that the deposition on oxide-free semiconductors is a new paradigm for already active research areas such as metal nanoparticle deposition in the fields of plasmonics and nano-electronics.

Additional work included the fabrication and deposition of gold nanoparticles on the modified surface as an extension of the work to other avenues. Initial results support the idea that well-controlled deposition of metal nanoparticles is possible on such modified surfaces depending on the molecule type.

 This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology. As such, this fellowship has increased collaboration between the US and ...

The work was completed in collaboration with Professor Jianhua Zhao's group at the State Key Laboratory of Superlattices and Microstructures, Institute of Semiconductors, Chinese Academy of Science in Beijing, CN. Professor Zhao is an expert in her field of nanostructure growth and characterization, providing an exemplary environment to carry out the desired project. The research is instrumental in my personal progression towards obtaining my doctoral degree while providing significant advancement in the topic of molecular deposition on semiconductors. Nano fabrication is an imperative avenue for the continued miniaturization of every day devices. Much work has been completed on synthesis and characterization of nanostructures, focusing on both metals and semiconductors, but one of the current issues preventing advancement is devising a way to self-assemble the nanostructures in highly specified, complex patterns. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology. As such, this fellowship has increased collaboration between the US and China, a relationship that shuold be nurtured. Last Modified: 02/27/2015 Submitted by: Tim...
